Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Deciphering and Engineering Biological State Machines with Synthetic Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biology is full of rich and complex systems where the interplay between past events, present inputs, and genetics determines cellular behavior. For example, stem cells are in a pluripotent "state" in which they can self-renew and also transform into diverse cell types with distinct functions, such as skin, bone, and blood cells, based on the timing and identities of regulatory signals. These properties require cells to store memory and perform computations, similar to modern computers. To understand such systems, the investigator proposes that biological systems can be thought of as state machines, in which the identity and function of a cell as well as transitions between these cell "states" are determined by past events and present inputs. The research team will build synthetic gene circuits that implement artificial biological state machines along with algorithms to guide their design. The research team will experiment on these circuits to quantify and gain insights into their behavior.

BROADER IMPACTS. To ensure broad impacts, the investigator will establish a new course called Biological Circuit Engineering Laboratory (BioCEL) to educate interdisciplinary scientists at the intersection of biology and engineering and will provide these teaching materials openly to the public. Furthermore, the investigator will engage high school, community college, and university students with opportunities for hands-on research. The investigator will create competitive games that teach the concepts used in this research to the general public. Finally, the investigator will establish an online resource to share the algorithms and circuits developed in this project to encourage their use by the broader scientific community. The creation of new design strategies for biological state machines is expected to shed insights into natural biological systems and advance important basic science, biotechnology, and biosensing applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DNA stores the blueprints of all living organisms. Synthetic DNA memory re-directs this natural function of information storage. DNA memory can be used to great advantage by scientists to understand life processes such as ageing, to find cures for diseases, and to develop miniaturized platforms to encode many kinds of information. One application of synthetic DNA memory is biosensing: for example, bacteria implanted in electronic devices are being engineered (or “trained”) to detect environmental toxins or biomarkers of disease, and to report their presence as a detectable signal to facilitate bio-remediation following an oil spill or the release of a chemical toxin, or to diagnose a disease earlier or more accurately than is now possible.

This project began with the construction of recombinase-based state machines, which are analogous to electronic state machines in that they integrate inputs and registers via combinatorial logic. In our cellular state machines, chemical inducers serve as inputs, a DNA molecule serves as a register, and input-driven recombination events (which get recorded) on the register are set in motion by serine recombinases, a ubiquitous class of enzymes found in both bacterial and mammalian cells.

Each recombinase enzyme recognizes a cognate pair of DNA recognition sites. When the sites are oriented with opposite polarity, their recombination inverts the DNA sequence between them, whereas when the sites are oriented with the same polarity, their recombination excises the intervening DNA. Earlier recombinase-based finite state machines, which used one pair of recognition sites per recombinase, could only perform particular order-dependent operations at the cost of others. Instead, we built registers that use, per recombinase, multiple pairs of orthogonal recognition sites. Our strategy yielded six pairs of orthogonal and directional recognition sites per recombinase. We built a 2-input, 5-state cellular state machine and then scaled it to a 3-input, 16-state system. Our recombinase-based state machines record and respond to all identities and orders of gene regulatory events in living cells.

DNA can also be manipulated by “DNA writing.” An event may occur in a cell so transiently that there is no way to know it happened: DNA writing can record that event, serving effectively as memory. Genetically encoded memory enabled by DNA writing can be designed to remain stable even after the initial stimulus is removed or the cells die. DNA writing works by modifying DNA, which can be done in various ways, including the use of recombinases described above: parts (sequences or the single constituent bases) can be deleted; new parts can be inserted;  and a part can be inverted by cutting out a sequence and putting it back in the opposite direction. Each of these modifications can be used to represent a distinct event, or memory state.

We had constructed a DNA writer (Synthetic Cellular Recorder Integrating Biological Events; SCRIBE) that required specific recombination mechanisms and was limited to bacteria. We improved that platform, making it more efficient and usable in eukaryotic (nucleated) cells, including human cells.  We have now built a highly scalable, robust, compact platform in which mutations introduced by DNA writing can be considered as unidirectional transitions between DNA memory states. This platform, DNA-based Ordered Memory and Iteration Network Operator (DOMINO), converts DNA in cells into an addressable, readable, and writable computation and storage medium encoding logic and memory operations in living bacterial and human cells. DOMINO works by leveraging CRISPR base editors to manipulate DNA dynamically and efficiently at single-nucleotide resolution. DOMINO can be used for both digital and analog computation, as it builds highly compact and scalable logic and memory operators that can be combined with gene regulatory circuits to create sophisticated genetic programs. Our DOMINO circuits advance biocomputing by coordinating the activity and timing of multiple molecular recorders.

DOMINO can record the intensity and duration of signals of interest (i.e., analog information) in DNA. Multiple DOMINO operators can be layered to record multiple signals and to scalably build logic operations in living cells. The order and combinations of DNA writing events mediated by multiple molecular recorders can be coordinated and tuned by external inputs, to execute several types of  logic and memory operations: order-independent (IF EVER A AND IF EVER B), sequential (A AND THEN B), and temporal (A AND THEN B after time X). Combined with established CRISPR-based gene regulation strategies, DOMINO can achieve modular and versatile memory and gene regulatory functions.

DNA writing enables us to build molecular recorders and living biosensors for the study of signaling dynamics in biological processes, to rationally design genetic memory elements and computation operations in living cells, to trace cellular lineages during embryonic development, and to study the differentiation of cells into the various cell types and tissues that constitute the human body. Our work in this exciting new arena represents a significant advancement, the full range of whose applications is yet to be discovered.
